Award.AwardTitle: A Periodic Table of Protein Domains
Award.AbstractNarration: This award in the Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) program of the Chemistry Division and cofunded by Molecular Biophysics in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience supports work by Professor George D. Rose at Johns Hopkins University to carry out fundamental studies on the theory of protein domains. Proteins are the workhorses of all living systems, responsible for essentially every vital task that takes place in cells. Each protein is a linear chain of amino acid residues that folds into an exquisite three-dimensional structure, one well suited to perform its specialized biological task. The three-dimensional structures are made from a limited number of structural building blocks called domains: the smallest proteins consist of a single domain; larger proteins are composites of multiple domains. Today, the experimentally-determined structure of more than 65,000 proteins is known in atomic detail, and several domain databases have been extracted from these data. However, at present there is no theory of protein domains. The overall goal of this research is to provide such a theory, one based entirely on the physical-chemical properties of polypeptide chains in water, not simply an enumeration from known structures. However, comparison against the known structures would be used to validate the theory. Among the broader impacts, this work would provide a complete "parts list" for experimental structure determination and useful tools for ongoing research in synthetic biology. Beyond these practical applications, a compact theory of protein domains would have a transformative impact on our understanding of protein evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome: Globular proteins are the workhorses of  living systems, responsible for carrying out almost all biological tasks.  Large, complex proteins can be decomposed into fundamental building blocks, called domains. An individual domain is a structurally distinct, quasi-autonomous protein component that is often, but not always, associated with a specific biological function. Domains can be further subdivided, iteratively, into ever smaller subdomains, resulting in a now familiar and ubiquitous hierarchic protein architecture. Today, the structure of more than 80,000 proteins has been determined, and several domain databases have been extracted from these data. However, at present there is no general theory of protein domains. Our overall goal is to provide such a theory, one based entirely on the physical-chemical properties of polypeptide chains in water.

 

Impact & Benefits:  We hypothesize that the entire set of conceivable protein domains is an automatic consequence of the chemistry of polypeptide chains in water. It follows that domain conformations were pre-determined, before the first protein was ever realized in a life form. Only a few thousand domains are possible, consistent with both current estimates and simple physical arguments. A corollary to this hypothesis is that nature cannot invent domains de novo, only populate pre-existing ones. The complete set of protein domains – enumerated from principles rather than guessed from empirical observation – would be the evolutionary equivalent of a periodic table of elements. Such a table would transform evolutionary biology, analogous to the way the periodic table has transformed chemistry

 

Background & Explanation: One reason why this is a hard project is that three-dimensional space is complex. Accordingly, the initial phase of the project focused on re-representing protein structures as one-dimensional strings using a conformational alphabet. String comparisons and string manipulations are both simpler and more revealing than three-dimensional comparisons, providing that essential structural information is retained in the 3D → 1D mapping. Several enabling components were also developed during this two-year period, including an analysis showing that the classical Ramachandran plot is abridged significantly when hydrogen-bonding is added to steric considerations. The abridged region corresponds to type I turn conformation, and surprisingly, this seemingly modest change has widespread simplifying ramifications for the set of allowed conformations.
